<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 238, 175, 248]]<|/det|> NUMBER <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 291]]<|/det|> **9702/22** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 2 AS Structured Questions **May/June 2012** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[852, 323, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 362, 368, 373]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 386, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 325, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 607, 460]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 597, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 632, 528]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 532, 225, 542]]<|/det|> appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 558, 600, 569]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 652, 597]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 555, 905, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 677, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 848, 121]]<|/det|>
The volume \(V\) of liquid flowing in time \(t\) through a pipe of radius \(r\) is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 135, 536, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{V}{t} = \frac{\pi Pr^4}{8Cl}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 189, 875, 221]]<|/det|>

where \(P\) is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of length \(l\) , and \(C\) depends on the frictional effects of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 236, 875, 253]]<|/det|>

An experiment is performed to determine \(C\) .The measurements made are shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 274, 785, 357]]<|/det|>

\(V\over t\)/10-6m3s-1\(P/10^{3}Nm^{-2}\)\(r/mm\)\(l/m\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground and rebounds as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 351, 875, 400]]<|/det|>
<pre>As the ball passes A, it has a speed of \(8.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The height of A is \(5.0 \text{m}\) above the ground. The ball hits the ground and rebounds to B. Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 414, 180, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 414, 618, 432]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed of the ball as it hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 536, 875, 555]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ............................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 568, 185, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 568, 733, 586]]<|/det|>
Show that the time taken for the ball to reach the ground is 0.47 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 675, 876, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[900, 79, 944, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 873, 322]]<|/det|>
A copper wire has the same original dimensions as the steel wire. The Young modulus for steel is \(2.2 \times 10^{11} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\) and for copper is \(1.1 \times 10^{11} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 873, 368]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, sketch the variation with \(x\) of \(F\) for the copper wire for extensions up to \(0.25 \text{mm}\). The copper wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 805, 92]]<|/det|>

<form>For Examiner's Use</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 259, 144, 278]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 259, 873, 292]]<|/det|>
Describe an experiment to determine the wavelength of sound in air using stationary waves. Include a diagram of the apparatus in your answer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 875, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 873, 107]]<|/det|>
The variation with distance \(x\) of the intensity \(I\) of a stationary sound wave is shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 78, 944, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use</FORM>
